crops.name: Tomato
crops.title: Complete Guide to Growing Tomatoes
crops.description: Learn how to grow delicious, juicy tomatoes from seed to harvest with this comprehensive guide.

growingSteps.title: Selecting Tomato Varieties
growingSteps.description: Choose between determinate (bush) varieties that fruit all at once or indeterminate (vining) varieties that produce throughout the season. Popular varieties include Beefsteak, Cherry, Roma, and Heirloom tomatoes.
tips: Consider your climate and growing season length
Determinate varieties are better for containers and small spaces
Indeterminate varieties provide longer harvests but require staking

growingSteps.title: Starting Seeds Indoors
growingSteps.description: Start tomato seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before the last expected frost date. Use seed-starting mix in small containers with drainage holes.
tips: Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep
Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy
Provide 14-16 hours of light daily using grow lights

growingSteps.title: Preparing the Garden Bed
growingSteps.description: Tomatoes thrive in well-draining, fertile soil rich in organic matter. Prepare your garden bed by removing weeds and amending soil with compost.
tips: Conduct a soil test to check pH levels
Add aged compost or well-rotted manure to improve soil structure
Consider raised beds for better drainage in clay soils

growingSteps.title: Transplanting Seedlings
growingSteps.description: Transplant seedlings outdoors after all danger of frost has passed and soil temperatures reach at least 60째F (16째C).
tips: Harden off seedlings by gradually exposing them to outdoor conditions for 7-10 days
Plant deeply, burying 2/3 of the stem to encourage root development
Space plants 24-36 inches apart

growingSteps.title: Supporting Your Plants
growingSteps.description: Install support structures like cages, stakes, or trellises at planting time to avoid damaging roots later.
tips: Tomato cages work well for determinate varieties
Use 6-8 foot stakes for indeterminate varieties
Secure plants to supports using soft garden twine or cloth strips

growingSteps.title: Watering Properly
growingSteps.description: Water deeply and consistently, providing about 1-2 inches of water per week, adjusted for rainfall.
tips: Water at the base of plants to keep foliage dry and prevent disease
Use drip irrigation or soaker hoses when possible
Mulch around plants to retain moisture and reduce weeds

growingSteps.title: Fertilizing Schedule
growingSteps.description: Apply a balanced fertilizer when planting, then switch to a lower nitrogen, higher phosphorus and potassium formula once flowering begins.
tips: Avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers which promote foliage at the expense of fruit
Apply compost tea or diluted fish emulsion every 2-3 weeks
Consider calcium supplements to prevent blossom end rot

growingSteps.title: Pruning and Maintenance
growingSteps.description: Remove suckers (shoots forming in the crotch between branches) to improve air circulation and focus plant energy on fruit production.
tips: Prune in the morning when plants are dry
Remove lower leaves that touch the soil to prevent disease spread
Pinch off growing tips of indeterminate varieties 30 days before first frost

growingSteps.title: Pest and Disease Management
growingSteps.description: Monitor plants regularly for common pests like hornworms, aphids, and diseases like early blight and powdery mildew.
tips: Rotate crops yearly to prevent soil-borne diseases
Use companion planting with basil or marigolds to deter pests
Apply organic treatments like neem oil at the first sign of problems

growingSteps.title: Harvesting and Storage
growingSteps.description: Harvest tomatoes when they reach full color and give slightly to gentle pressure. Pick regularly to encourage continued production.
tips: Use pruning shears to cut fruit from the vine rather than pulling
Store ripe tomatoes at room temperature, not in the refrigerator, for best flavor
Harvest all tomatoes before the first frost, including green ones which can ripen indoors

commonProblems.symptoms: Dark, sunken spots on the bottom of fruits
commonProblems.causes: Calcium deficiency, usually from inconsistent watering
commonProblems.solutions: Maintain even soil moisture, add crushed eggshells or calcium supplements to soil

commonProblems.symptoms: Dark spots with concentric rings on lower leaves that gradually spread
commonProblems.causes: Fungal infection, often splashed from soil onto leaves
commonProblems.solutions: Mulch to prevent soil splash, remove affected leaves, apply organic fungicide

commonProblems.symptoms: Circular or radial cracks on the top of tomatoes
commonProblems.causes: Rapid growth from fluctuating water supplies
commonProblems.solutions: Water consistently, harvest fruits slightly earlier during rainy periods

seasonalCare.spring: Prepare beds, start seeds indoors, harden off and transplant seedlings after last frost.
seasonalCare.summer: Monitor water needs closely, especially during hot periods. Provide shade if temperatures exceed 95째F (35째C).
seasonalCare.fall: Harvest remaining fruits before frost, remove and dispose of plants at season end to prevent disease carryover.
seasonalCare.winter: Plan next year's garden rotating tomato location, start collecting eggshells for calcium supplementation.

crops.name: Wheat
crops.title: Complete Guide to Growing Wheat
crops.description: Learn everything about wheat cultivation from soil preparation to harvest with this comprehensive guide.

growingSeason.plantingTime: Fall for winter wheat, spring for spring wheat

growingSteps.title: Selecting Wheat Varieties
growingSteps.description: Choose between winter wheat (planted in fall, harvested in summer) and spring wheat (planted in spring, harvested in late summer). Consider hard wheat (higher protein, good for bread) or soft wheat (lower protein, good for pastries).
tips: Winter wheat typically yields more than spring wheat
Select varieties suited to your climate and growing conditions
Consider disease-resistant varieties for your region

growingSteps.title: Soil Preparation
growingSteps.description: Wheat prefers well-draining, loamy soil with moderate fertility. Prepare your field by removing weeds and rocks, then till to a depth of 6-8 inches.
tips: Conduct a soil test to determine pH and nutrient needs
Adjust pH to 6.0-7.0 using lime or sulfur as needed
Incorporate compost or well-aged manure to improve soil structure

growingSteps.title: Planting Techniques
growingSteps.description: Plant wheat seeds 1-1.5 inches deep in rows spaced 6-7 inches apart. For winter wheat, plant 6-8 weeks before the first expected frost. For spring wheat, plant as soon as soil can be worked.
tips: Use a seed drill for larger areas or broadcast by hand for smaller plots
Plant at a rate of 2-3 pounds per 1,000 square feet
Ensure good seed-to-soil contact by lightly rolling after planting

growingSteps.title: Watering Requirements
growingSteps.description: Wheat needs about 16-24 inches of water throughout its growing season. Crucial periods for watering are during germination, tillering (when additional stems develop), and grain filling.
tips: Monitor rainfall and supplement with irrigation as needed
Avoid overwatering, which can lead to disease and lodging (falling over)
Reduce irrigation gradually as grain begins to mature and dry

growingSteps.title: Fertilizing Wheat
growingSteps.description: Apply a balanced fertilizer before planting based on soil test results. Nitrogen is particularly important for wheat growth.
tips: Apply nitrogen in split applications: at planting and again during active growth
Avoid excessive nitrogen, which can cause lodging
Consider foliar applications of micronutrients if deficiencies appear

growingSteps.title: Weed Management
growingSteps.description: Control weeds, especially during the early growth stages when wheat is most vulnerable to competition.
tips: Use pre-emergent herbicides before planting if necessary
Cultivate between rows in small plantings
Consider dense planting to help wheat outcompete weeds

growingSteps.title: Monitoring Growth Stages
growingSteps.description: Understand wheat growth stages from germination through tillering, stem elongation, heading, flowering, and grain filling to maturity.
tips: Each stage has different management requirements
Document growth progress to improve future plantings
Use growth stages to time fertilizer, pest control, and irrigation

growingSteps.title: Pest and Disease Management
growingSteps.description: Monitor for common wheat pests such as aphids, armyworms, and diseases like rust, powdery mildew, and Fusarium head blight.
tips: Scout fields regularly for early detection
Use crop rotation to break disease cycles
Apply appropriate treatments at the first sign of problems

growingSteps.title: Determining Harvest Readiness
growingSteps.description: Wheat is ready to harvest when kernels are hard and cannot be dented with a fingernail. The crop should have turned from green to golden, and moisture content should be around 13-14%.
tips: Conduct a sample harvest to check grain moisture
Harvest on a dry day to prevent moisture issues
Plan harvesting for early morning or evening in hot climates

growingSteps.title: Harvesting and Processing
growingSteps.description: Harvest wheat using a combine for larger areas or cut by hand for small plots. After harvest, wheat must be threshed to separate grain from chaff, then cleaned and dried for storage.
tips: For small plots, cut wheat stalks and bundle into sheaves to dry
Thresh by beating dried stalks against a tarp or using a mechanical thresher
Store cleaned grain in airtight containers in a cool, dry place

commonProblems.symptoms: Orange-brown pustules on leaves and stems
commonProblems.solutions: Plant resistant varieties, apply fungicides preventatively, maintain good air circulation

commonProblems.symptoms: Plants falling over, especially after heavy rain or wind
commonProblems.causes: Excessive nitrogen, weak stems, or heavy grain heads
commonProblems.solutions: Avoid over-fertilization, select varieties resistant to lodging, plant at appropriate density

commonProblems.symptoms: Bleached spikelets on the head, often with pink or orange fungal growth
commonProblems.causes: Fungal infection, especially during flowering in humid conditions
commonProblems.solutions: Plant resistant varieties, apply fungicide at flowering stage, practice crop rotation

seasonalCare.spring: For winter wheat: Apply nitrogen, monitor for pests and diseases. For spring wheat: Prepare soil and plant.
seasonalCare.summer: Monitor irrigation, prepare for harvest as wheat matures, harvest when ready.
seasonalCare.fall: Plant winter wheat, prepare fields for next season's spring wheat.
seasonalCare.winter: Monitor winter wheat for snow cover which provides insulation, plan for spring planting.

crops.name: Corn
crops.title: Corn Cultivation: Best Practices
crops.description: Maximize your corn yields with these proven techniques and tips from planting to harvest.

growingSeason.plantingTime: Late spring when soil temperatures reach 60째F (16째C)
growingSeason.harvestTime: Mid to late summer, 18-24 days after silking

quickStats.spacing: 8-12 inches between plants, 30-36 inches between rows

growingSteps.title: Selecting Corn Varieties
growingSteps.description: Choose between sweet corn (for fresh eating), field corn (for animal feed or grinding), popcorn, or ornamental corn. Consider days to maturity and how it fits your growing season.
tips: Sweet corn varieties include normal sugary (SU), sugary enhanced (SE), and supersweet (Sh2)
Plant corn varieties with similar days to maturity to ensure synchronized pollination
Consider disease-resistant hybrids for your specific region

growingSteps.title: Soil Preparation
growingSteps.description: Corn is a heavy feeder requiring fertile, well-draining soil. Prepare your garden bed by removing weeds and incorporating compost or well-rotted manure.
tips: Test soil pH and aim for 5.8-6.8
Add balanced fertilizer according to soil test results
Consider adding extra phosphorus and potassium which promotes strong root development

growingSteps.title: Planting Techniques
growingSteps.description: Plant corn seeds 1-2 inches deep when soil temperatures reach at least 60째F (16째C). Space seeds 8-12 inches apart in rows 30-36 inches apart.
tips: Plant in blocks of at least 4 rows rather than single rows to ensure proper pollination
Stagger plantings 2 weeks apart for extended harvest
Consider using a soil thermometer to ensure proper planting temperature

growingSteps.title: Watering Requirements
growingSteps.description: Corn needs consistent moisture, especially during tasseling, silking, and ear development. Provide 1-2 inches of water per week, adjusted for rainfall.
tips: Use drip irrigation to deliver water directly to the soil
Water deeply to encourage deep root growth
Critical watering periods are during pollination and grain filling

growingSteps.title: Fertilizing Schedule
growingSteps.description: Apply fertilizer in three stages: at planting, when plants are 12 inches tall, and when tassels begin to form.
tips: Use a balanced fertilizer at planting
Side-dress with nitrogen when plants are 12 inches tall
Apply additional nitrogen when tassels begin to form
Avoid getting fertilizer on leaves or stalks to prevent burning

growingSteps.title: Weed Management
growingSteps.description: Control weeds, especially during the first 6 weeks of growth when corn is establishing itself and most vulnerable to competition.
tips: Mulch around plants to suppress weeds
Cultivate shallowly to avoid damaging corn roots
Hand pull weeds close to stalks to avoid root disturbance

growingSteps.title: Supporting Pollination
growingSteps.description: Corn is wind-pollinated, requiring pollen from the tassels (male flowers) to reach the silks (female flowers) for ear development.
tips: Plant corn in blocks rather than long single rows to improve pollination
Gently shake stalks on calm days to help distribute pollen
Hand pollinate by collecting tassels and brushing them against silks if necessary

growingSteps.title: Pest and Disease Management
growingSteps.description: Monitor for common corn pests such as corn borers, earworms, and diseases like corn smut and leaf blight.
tips: Scout regularly for pests and diseases
Consider Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) products for caterpillar control
Apply a few drops of mineral oil to silk ends to deter earworms

growingSteps.title: Determining Harvest Readiness
growingSteps.description: Sweet corn is ready to harvest when kernels are plump, silks have turned brown, and kernels exude a milky liquid when punctured.
tips: Check ears 18-24 days after the first silks appear
Peel back a small section of husk to check kernel development
Harvest in the morning when sugar content is highest

growingSteps.title: Harvesting and Storage
growingSteps.description: Harvest corn by grasping the ear firmly and twisting downward. Consume sweet corn quickly for best flavor or preserve promptly.
tips: Sweet corn begins converting sugar to starch immediately after picking
Refrigerate harvested ears uncovered to maintain sweetness
Blanch and freeze extra corn to preserve it at peak quality

commonProblems.symptoms: Caterpillars feeding on ear tips and kernels
commonProblems.causes: Adult moths laying eggs on silks
commonProblems.solutions: Apply several drops of mineral oil to silk ends after pollination, use Bt products, choose resistant varieties

commonProblems.symptoms: Gray-white galls that eventually turn black and powdery
commonProblems.causes: Fungal infection that enters through wounds or young tissue
commonProblems.solutions: Remove and destroy galls before they break open, practice crop rotation, avoid mechanical damage to plants

commonProblems.symptoms: Ears with missing or partially filled kernels
commonProblems.causes: Inadequate pollination, water stress during silking, or nutrient deficiencies
commonProblems.solutions: Plant in blocks for better pollination, ensure adequate water during silking, proper fertilization

seasonalCare.spring: Prepare soil, wait for proper soil temperature, plant seeds, protect from late frosts.
seasonalCare.summer: Monitor water needs closely, especially during tasseling and silking, fertilize as needed, harvest as corn matures.
seasonalCare.fall: Remove plant debris after harvest, consider cover crops for the corn plot.
seasonalCare.winter: Plan next year's rotation, order seeds, analyze previous season's results.
